Why did you decide to stop working on i'm a princess at one point and start here comes the sun?

i did a heck of a lot in between. i stopped working on i'm a princess because the world of 3D was so vast and overwhelming and i was so in love with it, i needed to get as deep as i could into it, which also requires some significant renovations, and i also got really into those too. Then finally when i had hit rock bottom and needed to pretty much 'make a video or die', i think i decided i wanted to start fresh, with something a little more straightforward. although in retrospect, 'princess' would have been pretty good there. but the other technical reason is because the video was already like 20% made in the old system, and i was certainly in no mood to go back to the old system, and yet i still desperately wanted to use the footage, because it was very sentimental to me, because it literally shows the moment where i fell in love with 3D. So i knew it was going to be somewhat of an odd case, a frankenstein project, that would have to be pieced together cleverly to combine old and new. a bit too complicated of an endeavor for me to attempt in the first go. in addition it obviously required character animation, for continuity purposes, which actually i was quite ready for because i developed most of that in early 2020. but i still wasn't ready for it yet. i tried a cameo in the 'sun' song to prepare

when you said you could see that 262147 didn't have a 7 in its factorization, how did you know that? since there is no easy rule for divisibility by 7

you can legally knock off the 7 from the right side. and it still will or won't be divisible by 7. do you see what i mean? so, imagine if you could make legal moves like this, until eventually you got it down to something you could recognize. So you can knock the 7 off. then you still have a 14 on the end. so obviously you can subtract 14 and you'll still be left with the same status of 7-ness (or non.) Then you're left with 262, and of course you can divide it all you want and that won't change the 7-ness either. so go ahead and divide it by 2, which is super easy, digitally. just halve the digits and it's 131. Ok so i already know that one is prime just because i know my primes up to at least there. but if you didn't know 131, you can of course subtract 21 (again, that won't change the 7-ness of the main number). so that brings you to 110 and you can drop the zero (again, dividing (by 10) won't change its 7-ness). so you drop the zero and it's 11, and please tell me you can tell by looking at it if 11 is divisible by 7 (it's not). so the original number couldn't have been, because we've only made legal moves up to here

see if the digits add up to 3, which they don't, then check for 7, so ditch the 21 and see if the 10 is a multiple of 7 which it's not, then check for 11 by subtracting it from 1021 which makes 101 (after you drop the zero at the end) and check if 101 is a multiple of 11 which you should know it's not because 101 is prime, then check for 13 by adding 39 to 1021 which makes 106 (after you drop the zero at the end) then divide by 2 to get 53 and check if that's a multiple of 13 which of course it's not because it's neighbor 52 already is, then check 17 by eliminating the 102 from the left of 1021 and you're left with 1 which is not a multiple of 17, then check 19 by adding it to 1021 and you get 104 (after dropping the zero at the end) and you probably already know 104 is not a multiple of 19 (divide it by 2 a few times and you'll just get to 13), then check 23 by adding 69 to 1021 to get 109 (after you drop the zero) which is prime so 23 is out, then check 29 by adding it to 1021 which makes 105 (after you drop the zero) which you might already know as just 7x15 so no 29s there, then you can check 31 by subtracting it from 1021 which makes 99 (after you drop the zero) and we all know that 99 is just 11x9 (without any 31s in it), then you can check 37 except i THINK we're already done because i think 37 squared is already higher than 1021 because 32 squared is 1024 (famously) so 37 squared can't be any lower than that. and if 37 squared is higher than 1021, then that means we're never gonna find any other prime factors higher than that, because, if we did, their partner factor would have to be something lower and we checked everything lower already, so 1021 is prime, so your answer is an earth shattering 1x1021

Any tips for learning bass?

throw yourself into a professional working band as soon as possible. But, in case it is a disease year, here's something else i can recommend: take your favorite songs, and delete the bass. This is pretty easy to do if you have a phone, tablet, or laptop. just play it without any headphones, and it automatically deletes the bass. then, make sure your bass IS plugged into something that is large so you can actually hear it (like an amp) and play along. Generally what i'm trying to say, get yourself into a situation where you are actually playing the bass role in songs, as soon as possible. that's pretty much where you are going to learn everything. Start out by just playing the root note of each chord (for example, if the chord is C, play the C note). Try to hold back from doing anything else just yet. but then pretty soon, as if by magic, you're automatically going to start doing everything you need to do and have a wild time

At the beginning of your most recent song, "got some money", when you say "and I wonder if I'm sad about the money that I have, what is the music there. Is there any name for it. Where it gets lower and lower and with the little bit at the end.

the best names i have for it is just the names of all the notes and chords. the notes are E, D#, C#, C in the melody. then i think you probably want to put the bass with it on the same notes, for beef, except on "have", i am definitely using a chord known as G#dominant7, and the important part of that chord in this case will be: you want the C note (melody) then you also want the F# note with that, somewhere in the harmony, and then you'd have G# in the bass. And i can't remember if i put the bass in G# (root of the chord) or C (with the melody), let me listen and check. ok yes the bass is on G#. Also i've harmonized the melody a 3rd above, so "money that i" will also have notes G#, F#, E, and then it seems for "have", instead of harmonizing a 3rd above, for that one i've used F# as the harmony note, as i said, to get the best results on that chord you need the F# and C notes to give it that twang. with the G# in the bass.
I also have a similar question for the line "and it makes me mad", which is about 35 seconds in. Same thing, what is the term for the music happening there. With emphasis on 'me mad'. That's all.

again, i can just tell you the notes. there's hardly any chords in here, except "mad". the bass is just wandering toward the important note (the "mad" chord), and the chord for mad could be pretty much described as D7 (D dominant7), and in this case, to get the sound you want there, really all you want is the note F# (in the melody), you want C also in the harmony, and you want D in the bass. that should do the trick

the more time i spend on working on a musical idea, the less excited i am about it. but i also feel that if i didn't spend much time on it, it would be bad. Eventually, i always end up not getting anywhere and i give up on my compositions. Any advice?

save them in a list. so even if you have to stop working on it, you're still not giving up on it. music is like weird magic voodoo that only seems to work when you are not trying and not paying attention. so just keep the ideas listed where they belong, and then as long as you've familiarized yourself with them, you'll probably come up with the answers without even trying, some other time when you least expect it. If you feel like you must finish it, you can also do that but you just need to be very patient and calm and sit with it, and don't be alarmed if you are too tense to get anything for several hours. if you are patient, it will come, i'm sure. it literally can't stay away forever. science tells us this

Most categories on this website lead to a page called billwurtz.com/(category name).html or some variation on it like dropping the .html. For some reason, the "scarmble" category leads to a page called billwurtz.com/anagrams/anagrams.html instead of billwurtz.com/scarmble/scarmble.html, why?

anagrams is what it actually is. but a lot of people don't know what 'anagram' means (a lot of people actually think it means acronym). so instead i've labeled it "scramble" except i've scrambled the letters slightly for 2 reasons: because it matches the style of many of the other categories, and also because it is relevant to that category itself. Also it's important to notice that none of the scrambled titles are ever scrambled when they appear in the URL. this is a decoration scheme which relies on the colors, and would not be done without the colors

How do I get past the feeling that I'll never make a piece of music that's as beautiful or emotionally moving as my favorite artists' works? I'm studying multiple artists' works like crazy, listening to what sounds, rhythms, and melodies work best, but I feel like everything I make would be a stripped-down parody devoid of any authentic meaning.

here's the one thing to realize about music (or art) which might make this whole puzzle start to make sense. it's a magic trick. it's a miracle. it's weird and strange, and the more the scientists try to figure out what the "right" answer is, the damn music will change again and find a new way to knock your socks off even more. So, knowing the paradoxical and mischievous nature of this, it's probably time to start looking at the other side of the coin here, and instead of trying to find something that's actually "right", try doing something "wrong" on purpose. you might be surprised by the results

When i play piano both of my hands want to do the same thing. How do i fix this?

first figure out what you want them to do. there are some key questions to ask first: are you playing by yourself? who has the melody? (your voice, your hand, someone else's voice or hand, etc). Who is playing bass? (your left hand, someone else,)... Who is playing the chords? (you, someone else)... The answer to these questions will determine what each of your hands should be doing. and then there are different strategies depending on how many jobs you have to do. In some cases, maybe your hands only have 1 job, in which case it's not a bad idea to put 1 hand behind your back

I want to try writing out the entirety of my songs before I start making them in a DAW, but I don't know how to read or write sheet music, do you have any advice?

yes. make small demos. what works best for me is i use a lyric sheet with references to the audio demo. so it looks like

tempo= 92
see recording 771 for timed run through
recoring 770 for more detailed demo / talk thru

lyric lyric lyric lyric lyric
lyric lyric lyric lyric lyric (recording 557)

lyric lyric lyric
lyric (recording 559)

and the recordings will be just a live vocal+keyboard demo and also explaining any other necessary details or instructions i might have. Usually i will also let the recordings run while i am trying to come up with the ideas, just to make sure i catch anything i come up with. then when i think i'm sure, then i'll jump to the next recording and demo it concisely and that will be the recording that is referenced in the lyric sheet. then of course when it's all done, do a timed run through on a click, where you might miss a couple of lyrics but the important thing is to see the proper road map, then, you can also have a more detailed one, where you may stop and clarify whatever you need

what sort of instrument do you use to fill in the chords in songs? The chords usually seem full and chordy but i can't hear what instrument is playing them. Is it some synth?

sometimes you can get magical results by combining 2 different ones. sometimes the results are even more magical if you sort of only play half the chord with one of the instruments. The trick is to just pick an instrument you have, then, go through the entire song and very carefully and inquisitively just sort of test the waters to see where you can get a word (note) in. i call this the sprinkle method, which has its advantages and disadvantages, but, the advantage is that sometimes the natural blending effect makes it sound like you have more magical instruments than you really have

i'm really upset because i feel like there's no point to me putting all these emotions on the internet through music to get zero views. i know that's very irrational and probably raises many questions like "am i sure i want to do this" and "am i doing this for other people rather than for myself". these questions have obvious answers to my conscious mind (yes i want to do this and no i'm not doing this for other people), but i wonder if another answer is lurking subconsciously. i'm trying to decide if i should take a break and find my intentions or maybe even find another outlet for my feelings. what do you think?

first, just sit yourself down (or stand up) and ask yourself if you truly want the views. If the answer is yes, (it certainly was for me), there is a 2-part strategy i can recommend. first, keep doing the content, regularly and ruthlessly, to the absolute greatest of your ability. then, (or at the same time), open up some social media accounts in your artist name and begin GENTLY but ruthlessly interacting with many many many people, in the most honest and genuine way you can. i should clarify that this strategy is tailored toward the person who's answer to the first question was a resounding 'yes', mostly because it takes a long long time to do it effectively. but it does work
